subject: Re: [junit] How to Test Private Methods Inside a Class
msgSnippet: Hi Cederic ... Not true, this is a common mussunderstanding, protected is /less/ restricted than package private so you get all you get from package private +
messageBody:
Hi Cederic
> I'm not sure if it's the easiest and fastest way... Making it protected
> means that your test class (or a class it uses) needs to extend that class.

Not true, this is a common mussunderstanding, protected is /less/
restricted than package private so you get all you get from package
private + that the functionality is available to extending classes
from any package.

>
> I still think that package protected gives you the best of both worlds: the
> method can be used from any class as long as it belongs to the same package,
> so the coupling is minimal.
>

I agree with you that package-private is a better choice since the
functionality you want to protect is available only to those classes
in the same package and not also to those that just extend your class
from any package.

I would pick this approach any day over tweaking access to private
methods via reflection. I also think that Andreas suggestion, creating
a public interface that exposes what you want to expose is good, but I
would opt for that sooner and not as a last resort.

I agree even more with previous posters that whan you feel that a
private method should be tested you should first and foremost think
about your design. If it is meaningful to test it is most likely
meaning ful to use and it may be baecause the method is in the wrong
place that you feel it should be private.

Heck, maybe the best way is to make it public, feel really about that
method being public and figure out where it should be when you
refactor.

/Regards
